reviewText: This is a good intermediate level yoga Video.  Shiva Rea has a calm style, and she is a model of grace as she moves from position to position.  Her sequences are smooth and they work together very well.  This is another of her "Yoga Matrix" DVD's.  That means that you can select different parts and put them together into anything from a 10 minute corpse pose to over 3 hours of EVERYTHING.You can adjust the difficulty by selecting different segments.  Some of them are easier than others.The setting is Santorini Greece.  If you like people doing yoga in front of exotic tranquil scenery, then you will appreciate the background vistas.  If you are just here for the Yoga, the backgrounds are not excessively distracting.I like doing yoga.  I have been doing if for 7(+) years, almost daily, and I have gained a great deal from my practice.  Although my personal preference is a vigorous power yoga, I found her DVD to be a decent workout - if just a little slow moving for me.  Some of her positions and transitions may be a bit difficult for beginners,  She does not offer any modifications and accommodations.  This is why I do not look at this as a beginners DVD.There are 2 "Bonus Features."  One is an interview with Shiva Rea.  She explains why she chooses Santorini as a location for the DVD and for Yoga retreats that she teaches.  She also talks about her life/teaching and her book.  The interview is not overlong - less than 1/2 hour.  There is also a "Prana Danda Yoga Movement Meditation" that runs just over 10 minutes.  She and a male partner do a moving series of exercises with a very flexible staff.  There is no explanation or instruction with this section.If you like Shiva Rea and have done a few of her videos, this is a good choice for you.  If you like Shiva Rea - from her articles or interviews, or if you have taken a class from her (She teaches in Santa Monica CA and in workshops/retreats all over the place), you might like this.  If want to check out Shiva Rea, but you are a beginner, I would not recommend this.  I would suggest Shiva Rea: Flow Yoga for Beginners.
summary: Great if you like Shiva Rea.

reviewText: This is a fairly advanced set of sixteen different flowing movements and meditations. Each one is either six minutes (the Meditations), ten minutes or twenty minutes.  The music is beautiful eastern music.  You can choose to have music plus narration of the movements, or only the music for each one.I took off one star due to the fact that the start of the entire thing, even before the menu, is a two minutes advertisement for more of the Shiva Rea Yoga DVDs.  Whenever you start the DVD you have to watch this or scroll through it before you can get to the menu.These scenery behind the yoga instructor is fantastic.  The woman who demonstrates the yoga is a model of gorgeous muscles and flexibility, and she is quite inspiring.These are flowing non stop movements, for which you should be advanced in the practice of yoga for many of them.  Of course you can do it at your own pace and hold a pose longer or skip poses you are not able to get into.  There is an attractive female voice continuously describing the poses as the instructor goes along, but I prefer to turn this off and just listen to the beautiful, soothing music.  The meditations are wonderful, and most yoga DVDs don't include these, but the music is so relaxing it puts me to sleep and I use it for that at night.Anyone who is not new to yoga is going to really enjoy the poses and movements.  This flows at a good pace and will give a mild cardio workout, as well as putting you into a wide variety of yoga poses. Many of these poses are extreme versions not normally found in a do it yourself yoga DVD.  I have always done slightly less advanced versions of most of the poses shown with equally effective results as one would get with extreme versions. So you may need to modify these poses based on your level of advancement, but still it's beautiful to watch and quite inspirational, showing what can be achieved with regular serious practice.This would easily be at least five stars without the initial advertisement which makes this a chore to set up each time I use it.

reviewText: During a recent audition on American Idol, a contestant stated that he was going to do a "jazzy" version of a song.  Harry Connick, Jr., was not impressed by his "jazzy" version, as it wasn't jazz - it was just this kid changing the tempo and adding some notes.  Harry was offended, because he himself is a jazz man, and he let contestant know.  A few months ago, I reviewed Jillian Michaels' Yoga Inferno DVD and said that it wasn't Yoga - and it's not.  She is not a certified Yoga instructor and she has no business doing a Yoga DVD.  Don't get me wrong - Jillian is great at what she does, which is designing calorie-blasting workouts to help you lose weight in the shortest amount of time.  But she is not a Yoga instructor and that DVD could cause injuries to people.  (For more on Yoga injuries, see the article [...].)Shiva Rea is a Yoga instructor, meaning she has taught Yoga classes, and she is also a Yoga teacher, meaning she has taught other people how to be Yoga instructors.  She leads retreats both at the Kripalu Center for Yoga and Health as well as in Kerala, India.  So yes, she knows Yoga.Though I had heard of Shiva Rea many times, I had not actually experienced a Yoga class led by her.  This DVD was shot in Santorini, Greece, which is just beautiful.  The DVD allows you to choose your own sequence from a Yoga Matrix.  There are three meditations, seven 20-minute vinyasa flow segments, one 10-minute core segment, and a savasana.  You can put these in any order that you like, hit Play, and then it will go through the segments in the order you chose.Overall, this is a decent DVD.  Shiva offers modifications for some of the poses, which is always nice.  I think that I just prefer an actual Yoga class over a DVD, because of the energy in the room.  When I practice at home, I just go through my own flow, without anyone leading.I always recommend that people who are new to Yoga begin in a classroom with a teacher, as you need someone who knows what they're doing to correct your alignment.
summary: Beautiful scenery, great that you can pick your own flow, offers modifications

reviewText: I have been practicing yoga for several years now, and regularly practice power vinyasa at a studio - but like many yogis, I enjoy periodically practicing at home.  I typically flow at home to the various Rodney Yee DVDs and I really enjoy his organic practice.I felt that the flows tended to be a bit fast, especially when moving through center to a warrior two and then back to a martial arts style pose, then back to warrior two... having to continually adjust my feet made me feel that I wasn't stable or grounded.  I prefer getting into a warrior two on one side then flowing into reverse warrior, triangle, and other poses where I don't have to continuously shift my feet into various positions.Several of the flows lack consistent direction.  I am an advanced yogi, but I felt that often I had to look up for cues.  Other yoga DVDs actually have narration that gives very good, yet gentle guidance.  Even in the more advanced, faster flows from other teachers, I felt myself following their voice cues so well that I only had to look up if there was something I was less familiar with.Starting with the sun salutations, I warmed up quickly and was in a light sweat.  By the time I had moved on to other flows, I felt myself cooling off.  This is due partly to the style of the flows and the movements.  They are good movements, but many have martial arts inspiration (seemed more like Tai Chi), and so are a little unfamiliar and not quite as intense.As a note about the salutations: these (and many of the flows on this DVD) are not traditional Vinyasa flows.  A more traditional Vinyasa flow opens with Sun A and then Sun B salutations for warm up - therefore warming into the core and the hips with crescent lunges and warrior one poses.  The salutations were pretty basic, less adding on, and there were a few interesting modifications, such as a Sun A with going into a low lunge rather than crescent lunge.  And the flow repeats without adding any other poses.  Good, but I don't need a DVD to tell me how to do 20 minutes of basic Sun A.A couple of positive notes: I did enjoy the scenery, which was quite nice.  Also, the ability to select each flow individually and queue them up for a long flow was very nice.  The music is also very nice.Overall it's a decent yoga DVD with some reservations.  Fans of Shiva Rea will enjoy it.  But for my practice I find Rodney Yee has been the best - especially his advanced flows.

reviewText: I'm already a fan of Shiva Rea, and this is my 5th dvd.  I own her Daily Energy, More Daily Energy, Vinyasa Flow for Beginners and her Core Yoga.  Her dvds all are beautifully done.  Excellent cuing, beautiful photography and in this video as well as her Energy videos have a yoga matrix, which means I can choose 1 section to do, or put them in any order I would like to set a longer or shorter practice as time allows.  The matrix lets me just mix and match the 20 minute practices.  There are also three meditations (10 minutes prox) as well as a 10 minute Shavasana (or Corpse pose).  The solar programs are for energizing and the lunar positions are more for winding down or when you feel your energy level is telling you to slow down and that you need something more restorative.  I tend to do the solar more just because I work out before I got to my work, but I also enjoy the grounding nature of the lunar poses and LOVE the extra long Shavasana.  You will find your sun salutations, planks, twists, down-dogs, cobras and the like here, so if you are familiar you should be able to follow along quite easily.  I would say this is an intermediate program, and she will occasionally will through in something she does that is advanced (normally, I stare at the screen trying to make sense of where she put her arms and legs and how she looks like a pretzel....I don't always try those moves).The dvd is shot on the Greek Island of Santorini and is beautiful.  As in all of her dvds the music is perfect, chanting in some spots, instrumental in others and always perfect for the routine.  Never too loud or distracting.The bonus items contain an "interview" where Shiva describes her experience in Greece, some of the geography of the island, and talks about the dvd and her retreats.  This section is a little under a half an hour.  There is also another flow where she is working with a man and they both have flexible sticks....very flowing, but not sure what the sticks are....this I have not seen before.Overall, I love this one as much as the others.  A good, sound practice, great filming, excellent instruction and beautifully put together.  I will continue to seek out her dvds.Recommended for intermediate yoga practitioners and those who are fans of her prior work.

reviewText: I have another Shiva Rea DVD which I love. I took about 3 years of Iyengar yoga, which is NOTHING like Vinyasa flow. If you don't know a lot about yoga- Iyengar works on perfecting postures. You stay in them for awhile, repeat a few times...you do not really transition in a flow style between poses. Hatha, Vinyasa....that's more of the type you'd find in a health club, where one move gracefully (or not so gracefully, if you are like me!) flows into the next.I love how Shiva's DVDs have the yoga matrix- you can mix and match parts to create huge variety in your workouts. I get bored with workouts easily, so I generally gravitate towards any workout DVD with a matrix. On this particular DVD, each matrix piece is about 20 minutes. The beginning meditation and savasana at the end are shorter (10min or less). Some of her other DVDs have matrix pieces with varied lengths; with this one though, your minimum yoga session will always be 20 minutes.Shiva is a great instructor- but she assumes that you know the poses already and often uses Sanskrit names, so I would say that if you are a complete beginner, this is NOT the DVD for you. If you're comfortable with the basic poses and are adept at learning less familiar ones as you go, you'll be fine.If you're like me- uncoordinated and not as good with the "flow" yoga, you'll struggle at first. But the more times you do the DVD, obviously, the more you'll catch on and the easier it will get.I highly recommend this DVD. It's very good quality, just like Shiva's other works; the background of Greece is spectacular; and like I mentioned before, you'll get so much variety with her matrix setup that this DVD will keep you busy for quite some time!
summary: Great workout- might take a little bet to get the hang of it, though

reviewText: As with all Shiva Rea offerings, these practices have a fluid, dance-like feel to them. That doesn't mean you'll be asked to execute any plies or pull of any jazz routines, but the transitions will be even more graceful than usual in yoga.The bulk of this disk are the eight vinyasa practices. There are three "lunar" practices and five "solar" practices. As expected, the solar practices are more vigorous, and the lunar practice accommodates hip opening. None of these are going to introduce you to new or unusual postures, but the transitions might feel a little different. Earth, which might the closest to "power yoga", uses fluid transitions that emphasize the hip opening action of the Warrior poses traditionally used in that school of yoga.While I find some of Rea's previous work to be over-the-top, I didn't find that the case here; all of the practices were approachable- although I strongly advise that you *not* practice any of these on a ledge as she does for one. However, she demonstrates a level of flexibility most participants probably aren't going to have particularly in some of the hip openers and back bends. As always, best to watch first and decide how you're going to modify for your body.As others have notes, the scenery is beautiful and warm; that alone might be half the value of these practices.Recommended for experience yoga practitioners.
summary: Fluid practice for more experienced practitioners

reviewText: Shiva Rea introduces her yoga DVD with the expected serene, other-worldly demeanor that one would deem typical for an instructor who had devoted thirty years of her life to this practice.  Indeed, she is extremely fit and can move and bend with the dexterity, strength and flexibility of a willow tree.  With over 25 DVDs under the belt of her slim fitting yoga pants, she teaches her own brand of "breath-inspired journeys" that combines the grounding of yoga with the fluidity of dance.  To paraphrase her intent, the resultant sequences are meant to cultivate the overall development of the body's wholeness with regard to such thing as the feeling of mind achieved, as pathways to evolution, or as energy discovery points that connect the participant's body flow with that of Nature. If yoga is your go-to exercise for strength building, stretching and flexibility and you appreciate the beauty of fluid movements done well, "Shiva Rea's Yoga in Greece" will treat you to sequences instructed in one of the most beautiful places on earth.In addition to the visual beauty projected by the stark whites of the sugar cube buildings, the transitioning greys and earth tones of the striated mountains and the cobalt blue of the sea sparkling in the caldera of an ancient volcano, the format concept of this video is amazing in its versatility and simplicity to use. The participant simply slides over to the menu option "Yoga Matrix" and then proceeds to peruse the programs offered from rows entitled: "Meditation," "Lunar" (refers to the calming, slower-paced, internal poses that are appropriate for any time of day, especially when the participant is seeking a soothing, rejuvenative practice), "Solar" (energetic vinyasa (breath-synchronized movementthat flows in a dance-like series) sessions that are based upon the solar power that each one of us embodies) and "Shavasana"(corpse pose). The duration of each of these segments is listed beneath it, enabling the participant to functionally create an exercise routine that fits into his/her time constraint for the day. Shiva Rea recommends that each personally tailored regimes ends with the ten minute Shavasana.Each of the titles with the exception of the Meditations and Shavasana are tailored towards someone who is either an experienced beginner or an intermediate practitioner.  With this in mind, watching the video beforehand can be helpful with regard to what is expected.  For extreme beginners, I would recommend something less challenging with more instruction and explanation.  Shiva Rea talks the talk and walks the walk, but that does not mean that everyone who watches this workout for the first time, no matter how beautifully executed, will understand her yogic vocabulary. In the Lunar and Solar segments--these categories offer the largest selection of options, Shiva Rea goes right into her flow with an awesomely enviable dexterity and grace.  Her movements are balletic and for this exerciser--more adept at kickboxing and more aggressive exercise--difficult to achieve without the intense focus of many repeated viewings.  Alas, as a student of yoga, I am a pre-schooler.However, that does not mean that I cannot appreciate the winsome beauty of Shiva Rea and her good intentions. For those more skillful and flexible than I, this meld of lunar and solar movements will indeed please.  And, if you simply love the landscapes of Santorini, Greece, you will definitely feel some aspect of her enthusiasm and magic empower you to at least try the programs.  Her three meditations are definitely something that I will listen to when I want to focus on nothing and relax--the six minute Mudra (spiritual gesture) in front of Skakros Rock is a tribute to endurance which I will turn to often, while the sunrise/sunset meditations are exquisite in their poetry and visual calming sensation--bringing the tradition of sun watching into your living/exercise room.  I would wish for something more in terms of the Shavasana--this is filmed by a pool lined with vases and some attractive candle holders (that I would love for my patio)--once Shiva Rea explains the concept, she quiets and a man's voice over speaks of bones a la Day of the Dead which, although appropriate seems wasted--I would have preferred more panoramic views of the magnificent Santorini setting.The extensive bonus material includes an interview with Shiva Rea where she speaks glowingly of her retreats on the island of Santorini--and indeed, the entire program filmed on this glorious island acts as a fabulous promotion for those who would love to experience more fully a lifestyle they attempt to follow in a setting that although has endured much physical tumult, is grounded in beauty.  Otherwise, I wish her interview had included more of an introduction to the material, her history with yoga and her personal philosophy.  Most beautiful is the addition of the Prana Danda Yoga Movement Meditation where Shiva Rea and a male counterpart dance with long flexible poles to music by Bahramji and Mashti--the eastern sounds of which serendipitously echo the mixed western and Asian cultures of the Greeks--another visual and audio treat.Bottom line?  For the price, Shiva Rea's Yoga in Greece is a veritable travel promotion for the magical island of Santorini.  While her lunar and solar sequences may not be for the extreme beginner or only occasional practitioner of yoga, the meditations, Shavasana and Prana Danda Yoga Movement Meditation are stellar from this reviewer's (long-time kickboxer and runner) vantage point. Recommended for those who have practiced yoga before and are aware of the poses and the expected flow and for anyone who wants to experience the timeless landscapes of Santorini.Diana Faillace Von Behren"reneofc"
summary: Beautiful Scenery Compliments A Variety of Yoga Sequences

reviewText: I recently received a painful reminder that I can no longer skip flexibility training at my age.  While sparring during a kickboxing class I strained my right calf muscle, which was still tight after a boxing lesson the day before.  After I limped home, I decided that I needed to do at least one yoga session a week, and preferably more.  However, my yoga time limit runs between 20 to 40 minutes - I've done as long as 1.5 hours, and that's just yoga overload.  With that in mind, I look for yoga DVDs that feature practices of the desired length, and Shiva Rea: Yoga in Greece fit the bill.  Indeed, a single disc containing *seven* 20-minute routines seemed like just the ticket, and I was not disappointed.After an advertising montage that I was unable to skip, the disc arrives at the main menu featuring a brief introduction by Shiva Rea, audio options that allow you to choose either music and instruction or music only, bonus materials that include an interview with Ms. Rea, and the Yoga Matrix.  The matrix contains four sections: Meditation, with three meditations of 6-10 minutes; Lunar, with three 20-minute practices; Solar, with four 20-minute practices and a 10-minute core routine; and Shavasana, with one 10-minute routine that is the recommended end for whatever practice you construct.Once you complete your desired practice using your DVD remote within the Matrix, you select the Play menu and begin.  Ms. Rea instructs using voice-over, offering some options here and there.  She leans heavily toward the mystical, so keep that in mind if such things bother you. I'm not into meditation, so I skipped those choices in favor of the 20-minute practices I wanted (I watched parts of the meditations, and they consist of sitting cross-legged while being verbally guided by Ms. Rea).As for the 20-minute practices, I did four of them, including finishing one with the recommended Shavasana, which mainly consists of lying on your back and achieving a state of relaxation.  The New-Age style music is quite soothing in the practices, and the beautiful Santorini locale made me want to book a ticket to Greece.  Ms. Rea's instruction is easy to follow, with a soothing California hippie tone that fits yoga like a glove.  Depending on your level of fitness, some of the practices will be more difficult than others - for example, the Sun Salutation practice contains a lot of planks and gets faster as it goes along, so it's quite the workout on its own.  Others, like the Water Vinyasa, are akin to a Tai-Chi routine.Overall, Shiva Rea:Yoga in Greece was a yoga disk that I was looking to add to my collection, one that had a number of 20-minute practices that would get me in the habit of doing yoga on a regular basis.  The additional Matrix add-ons are a bonus in case I want a little more Greek-themed relaxation, but for now I'm quite happy going with the flows.  I especially recommended this disc for anyone who wants to try yoga but is intimidated by long or difficult practices.

reviewText: This is a collection that I would only recommend to people who have some basic knowledge and experience with yoga.  There is a matrix of 12 different sets, and some are easier than others, but you will get lost quickly if you’ve never done yoga before.  I’m going to go through the 9 days that I used this combining the different sets, so you get an idea what this looks like.There are three beginning meditation sets – one at 6 minutes, the other two are 10 minutes each.Then there are eight ‘workout’ sets, all except one are 20 minutes.  One is 10 minutes (and it’s my favorite).And finally, the Shavasana set, which should end every workout.  So what you do then is choose one of three meditation sets to start, then select a workout and end with Shavasana.  The real challenge is in the workout you select.In the three meditations, I would say my favorite is the first one, the six minute one.  I think 10 minutes is too long.  The second one is the least active, and the third one has a bit of singing to your chakras, which is okay. If my back starts to hurt during one of these, I simply add some impromptu stretches.I have a hard time understanding her, so have to crank up the volume pretty high. She uses a real peaceful and rather low tone of voice.The nice thing about yoga – it’s all movement and breath and the rest of the world disappears.Here’s my analysis of the 8 workouts:1.  Sun Salutation.  This is repetitive, which makes it easy to pick up. But she goes faster and faster, so that by the end, you know you’ve had a workout.2. Moon Salutation.  This was also repetitive, but the movements remain at a steady tempo.3. Water Vinyasa.  I couldn’t do this one.  It requires great knee flexibility.  I may revisit at some point in the future.  Quite a few of these involved movements I could not do, but in some cases, you can adapt.  Here I couldn’t.4. Lunar Backbending Flow. I didn’t like this one.  It was very challenging.  You can either do the moves or you cannot.  Unlike some videos, you get little instruction on alternate moves.  Because she can be hard to understand when she’s talking, you find yourself having to watch the TV while moving, which also makes it hard. Yes, it would be recommended to watch it all the way through the first time, but that wouldn’t help me. I only learn by doing.5. Earth Vinyasa.  This one felt awkward and jerky. There’s a lot of arm work and balancing here.  Very challenging for balance.6. Solar Backbending Flow.  It’s okay, as long as by this time you’re used to the idea you’re not going to get all the moves right away, depending on your level of yoga abilities.  There’s a lot of bending here, making you feel like a pretzel at times—it will pull you, stretch you and keep you moving.  The time goes fast.7. Solar Core.  This is the 10 minutes I like.  A lot of core (stomach) work here, all on the floor on your back.  Great workout for the gut and for when you have little time. This one even ends with a little Shavasana.  You can easily modify this to fit your range.8. Earth-Water Vinyasa.  Very challenging.  She does these really fast so that you really don’t have much chance of keeping up.  But just do the best you can, and eventually, you might get there.  I got lost on this one and had to watch for a bit.  There’s a lot of stretching here, and some range of motion that seems impossible for most of us.One thing to remember – if you’re used to videos where their right is your right, you’ll find this is the opposite.  When she says right, it’s the opposite.  So you have to either follow her and not listen to her saying right or left, or know to use the opposite legs and arms, because she doesn’t always say which one she’s using. I hope that makes sense.One of the reasons I ordered this is because I love Greece.  But I was not impressed with the Greek scenery here.  If you’re new to yoga, you can just work with the sun and moon salutations for a while and the solar core, and do the meditations and shavasana.  This DVD will keep any yoga practitioner moving, of that, I’m sure.

reviewText: Rating: 4.5 starsI have only one other Shiva Rea DVD in my collection, "Shiva Rea A.M. Energy", and it took me a long time to reach some sort of level of comfort when doing two out of the three featured routines (I haven't even tried the third workout yet).  So when I decided to order "Yoga in Greece," I was a little bit hesitant but at the same time, I was curious about what new moves I could learn from it.  I'm glad to say that "Shiva Rea Yoga in Greece" has not disappointed me in any way.  The outdoors locations shot on the Greek island of Santorini are breathtaking and Shiva Rea's graceful movements and extensions are beautiful to watch and a worthy goal to aspire to.  However, all viewers should be realistic and move, flex and bend to their own degree of flexibility and ability."Yoga in Greece" is divided into four sections: Meditation, Lunar, Solar and Shavasana.  The DVD's Yoga Matrix makes it easy to select and combine workouts from all these sections.  The Meditation section is divided into three short meditations: Mudra (6 minutes), Lunar (10 minutes) and Solar (10 minutes). They are all seated meditations where viewers are invited to concentrate on breathing and on visualizations of the rising or setting of the moon or sun. The Lunar Meditation is my favorite because of the sound of bells incorporated in the background music; the Sun Meditation ends with chanting.The Lunar section is comprised of three 20-minute routines.  The first routine, Lunar Backbending, is a slow paced workout, which focuses on pigeon, double pigeon, side plank and bow poses variations. The main goal is to hold the pose and stretch.  Seated spinal twists with some challenging variations like the one-foot-to-head pose (eka pada sirana) are better left to people who are advanced practitioners and/or have a great degree of flexibility. Still if you are familiar with other Shiva Rea's DVD workouts, this is doable for the experienced beginners and intermediate students.  The second routine, Moon Salutation, will be welcomed by newbies to yoga. It is basically a sun salutation sequence that is repeated over and over.  The last routine in the Lunar section is Water Vinyasa. This one made me feel a little apprehensive, not because of the difficulty but because Shiva was demonstrating it on top a wall.  The Water Vinyasa is a graceful flow that starts with side stretches and then goes on to focus on downward/upward dog and cobra poses variations. There are some wheel poses and there is at least one pose that was too challenging for me.  There was no modification shown so if your flexibility doesn't allow it, it is better not to force yourself.  This routine is best suited for intermediate/advanced people.  However, some experience beginners may start trying out this routine.The Solar section of the DVD contains four 20-minute routines and a 10-minute one: Sun Salutations, Earth Vinyasa, Solar Backbending, Earth-Water Vinyasa and Solar Core (10 minutes).  All the workouts were shot outdoors. The pace is slow to moderate.  Sun Salutations is Surya Namaskar or Sun Salutation sequence, again repeated over and over.  The second routine, Earth Vinyasa, is a standing workout that combines warrior pose variations, yoga squats, and balancing on one leg.  Earth Vinyasa is a nice workout for beginners. Solar Backbending, the third routine, starts with graceful arm circles over one's head. Some of the poses included in this routine are: camel pose, plank and side plank, high cobra, dolphin, and combinations of standing split with half boat and chair poses with twists.  The last 20-minute routine is Earth-Water Vinyasa that will work your core and arms with variations of side inclined plane. Other poses included are: cobra, triangle combined with side angle poses, gate pose, eagle, yoga squats, warrior variations and the challenging cock pose (kukutasana).  This routine is best for intermediate to advanced levels.  Solar core is a short workout that concentrates on hip opening and core strengthening with a variety of crunches and leg raising and lowering moves.  The Shavasana section contains the 10-minute Lunar Shavasana or corpse pose.In spite of the fact that some poses are out of the range of my ability, I liked "Shiva Rea Yoga in Greece" a lot.  The instructor just has a very calming quality; watching her move so gracefully is a treat. Her cueing was good (but do watch the workouts at least once before trying them out) and I'm glad that in this DVD she is using the English terms for the poses more than in the earlier DVD that I have.  Except perhaps for the Meditation and Salutation routines, "Yoga in Greece" is not for newbies.  This DVD assumes some knowledge of yoga terminology and of previous yoga practice. And even then, viewers should modify those poses that are too difficult for them.  This is a gorgeous-looking DVD thanks to the locations chosen on the island of Santorini.  I enjoyed the different routines immensely even though I'm still a long way toward mastering them. But my favorite one is in the Bonus material: the Prana Dada Yoga Movement Meditation. There are no voice over instructions but I could follow it without much of a problem. This meditation is done with a staff or a bar that has to be as tall as you are.  Shiva and the man accompanying her used bendable staffs but I was quite happy using my stiff wooden bar.  This mediation is beautiful to watch but doing it is even better.

reviewText: I own several Shiva Rea DVD's and this one thus far is my favorite.  I have now done several combinations of practices from this DVD and I find it very well balanced between heating (Solar), cooling (Lunar/Moon), and grounding (Earth) poses.  While some of her other DVD's can be overwhelming with the amount of choices and length of each section, this DVD offers sections that you can customize via the matrix each ranging from 6-20 minutes of length each.  What is brilliant about this DVD is that if you feel you are in the driver's seat of what kind of practice you want to design.  If you want for example, a more cooling yoga practice you can pick all lunar and moon selections, or if you want a balanced practice you can pick one from the lunar, one from the solar, and one from the earth, or water if you like.The selections to choose from are as follows:3 Mediations:  Mudra, Lunar, Solar (ranging 6-10 minutes each)3 Lunar:  Lunar Backbend Flow, Moon Salutations, Water Vinyasa (all 20 minutes each)4 Solar:  Sun Salutations, Earth Vinyasa, Solar Backbend Flow, Earth & Water Flow (20 minuteseach), plus Solar Core (10 minutes)Shavasana  Lunar (10 minutes)Shiva Rea's voice is lovely and soothing, the pace is slow and fluid which feels like a devotion to the various elements.  The setting include a beautiful mountain top in Santorini (Earth), a white patio overlooking the ocean with full sun beaming down (Water/Sun), and an indoor candlelit room overlooking a still pool (Moon/Water).  Shiva Rea's style of movement is fluid and creative.  Her dance background really shines in this one.  She has an approach and creativity to the practice and poses that really is like no other.  One suggestion is to have your mat parallel to the screen  and you will need to do so the first couple of times as her Solar Vinyasa, is not the typical one you would find but rather very creative.  The poses themselves are what I would call intermediate to sometimes advanced Ashtanga like poses, but it is done at such a slow pace you won't find yourself frustrated  and moving from one pretzel like pose to another.  Even though I may not be able to do some of these poses, I like that they are there as something to aspire to.The SOLAR CORE is one of my favorite ab routines thus far because it does not feel like doing ab crunches.  It really feels like and extension of the yoga practice, is creative, fluid, and very effective.  It doesn't feel like you are doing ab crunches, but the movements are so subtle, much like pilates, you are dynamically working muscles.  The beauty of this routine is that you get a wonderful  hip release at same time as working your abs.  The glutes stretch felt so good, I did not even realize I was doing an ab crunch at the same time.  This is genius!All in all, this is a very well rounded and approachable practice set in a spectacular setting taught by an amazingly creative teacher.

reviewText: I am the owner of many Shiva Rea DVDs.  I have loved them all, although the Daily Energy is probably one of my favorites. I did find, using my heart-rate monitor, a significant difference in energy use between the Lunar Salutations flow and the Earth-Water Solar flow, for example.  Some of the twenty minute workouts are quite stragihtforward, like the sun salutations that are exactly that - standard sun salutations.  The lunar salutations are quite relaxing, with a lot of backbending.  I also did the earth-water flow, which involved a lot of side bends and side planks.  I also did the solar core, which was fairly straightforward as well - no "improvisation" as some of her other core workouts have.  I haven't been able to complete all the segments in the time I had to review.  Those that I did, I was struck by the simplicity of them, the clarity of the instruction also.  This DVD is definitely a return to the roots of yoga.All of it is new material, filmed in Santorini Greece, a beautiful backdrop and less stark than the deserts that many yoga instructors use as a backdrop. There are also shorter segments, meditations, and a solar core practice, and two shavasanas.
summary: a return to the roots of yoga, not as uniquely Shiva as other releases, but still very good.

reviewText: There's pretty much no facet of this DVD that didn't have both a good and a bad side.Take something as simple as the scenery. Santorini is one of the most beautiful places on earth, but in the Sun Salutation, there's a giant cruise ship parked in the harbor behind Ms. Rea. In the Water Vinyasa, she's practicing on a narrow ledge that, while i'm sure has another surface behind it, looks for all the world like if she loses her balance she might tumble down a cliff into the ocean.As a beginner (i did yoga at home with a DVD by another company for a while a few years ago, but i haven't done any since), i found the practice itself to vary wildly between manageable and impossible. To reference the Sun Salutation again, it's a relatively simple flow between poses, but she accelerates very quickly until i could barely keep up. On the other hand, even just sticking poses in where i could, that single starting session got me from not able to touch the floor with my fingertips keeping my knees straight to being able to press my knuckles to the floor, so it's definitely doing some good stretching.The narration was, again, a mixed bag. At times it's very high level, just calling poses and if you don't know what they mean, you're just trying to copy what she's doing on the screen. I'm sure i, like most beginners, will get most of them wrong because tips like 'put your hand under your shoulder' and other placement cues are few and far between. Other times, she's so busy sticking the verbal components of the flow in that she can barely even call the poses.There's even one section where she starts off assuming you're doing a mirror image of her poses (she puts her left leg forward and tells you to put your right leg forward), then in the middle, with no warning, switches (she puts her left leg forward and tells you to put your left leg forward).I'm also not sure how to do the Lunar cooldown bit, the one the matrix tells you to do at the end of every session, without dozing off. Ten minutes of soothing music during which i'm supposed to lie flat and relaxed? Sounds like a power nap to me.The matrix idea is neat, i'll admit that, but again it assumes you know your down dog from your viper, and you're on your own to assemble a 'good' sequence. You'll have to do a great deal of experimentation so you know each individual section and how they might fit together.I wouldn't recommend this for beginners, mostly because it seems designed for people with at least a moderate exposure to yoga. As i mentioned above, 99% of the time the narration assumes you know how to get into each pose, where your shoulders and hips and feet should be.
